title: Valleys have two sides
summary:
Key ideas
- The concept of uncanny valleys exist where getting halfway towards a noble aim is worse than not having any noble aim at all. 
- Uncanny valleys of dictatorship work completely differently; even if 51% of the population supports it, it'll still be an unstable dictatorship.
- Total control over a country is needed to defy the zeitgeist (the social norm on how to gain and keep power).

Key learnings
- Perfect unimpeded progress up the right side of the valley is better than attempted progress up the left side dragged down by lingering rightists.
- The opposite of attempted progress up the left side dragged down by lingering rightists is attempted progress up the right side dragged down by lingering leftists.
- Societies left to their own devices become more Progressive.

Key questions
- How are we going to get a perfectly secure despot with no fear whatsoever of rebellion when less than 1% of the population is in favor of such a despot?
- Might it be kind of embarrassing when Scott Aaronson builds a quantum computer that can factor prime numbers in polynomial time and then becomes the new god-emperor?
- Will Reaction be in the same position as the Communists, having to expend energy pumping against entropy to prevent societies from becoming more Progressive?
